questions.text: A villager was assaulted by 4-5 people & brought to hospital in serious condition. His dying declaration was being taken in hospital. What is correct regarding this process?

choices.text: Oath is compulsory before recording the statement

questions.solution:
• Ideally, a Magistrate should record the dying declaration to ensure authenticity and legality.
  • In exceptional cases, when a Magistrate is unavailable and death is imminent, a doctor or even a police officer may record the statement

questions.text: A man was abducted from his home, and his son subsequently claimed rights to his father’s property. As per Section 111 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA), until when is the son not entitled to claim inheritance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. 7 years

Explanation:

  • Section 111 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA) states that a person who has been missing and not heard of for 7 years by those who would naturally have heard from them is presumed dead. Until those 7 years are completed, legal heirs cannot claim inheritance. The burden of proving the fact of the missing lies on the person claiming the benefit of this presumption. For 7 years, property rights remain with the missing person’s estate, and heirs cannot take possession.

Incorrect Options:

5 years (Option A): No legal presumption of death at 5 years; heirs cannot claim property before the statutory period.

6 years (Option B): Falls short of the legal requirement; property rights remain frozen until 7 years.

10 years (Option D): Longer than required by law; Section 111 specifically sets the period at 7 years, not 10.

questions.text: A doctor receives two summons, one to appear in court in a murder case and another to provide expert medical opinion. Which of the following should the doctor prioritise?

choices.text: Appearance for providing medical expert opinion

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Appearance in the murder case

Explanation:

  • A criminal court summons in a murder case generally carries a legal imperative and higher priority; attendance is mandatory unless legally excused.
  • Providing expert opinion is important, but when faced with a direct court order in a criminal case, the legal obligation to appear in court for the criminal matter is prioritized.

Incorrect Options:

Appearance for expert opinion (Option B): Important but typically subordinate to a direct criminal court summons.

The summon received first (Option C): The timing of receipt does not override the legal gravity of a murder case summons.

questions.text: According to the Bharatiya Nyay Sanhita (BNS), which of the following is not classified as grievous hurt?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pain lasting for 5 days

Explanation:

Pain lasting for 5 days is incorrect as it does not meet the criteria for grievous hurt, as the law specifies a minimum duration of 15 days of severe bodily pain or inability to follow ordinary pursuits.

BNS 116 (Old Section 320 IPC) defines following injuries as grievous:

  1. Emasculation (cutting off the penis, castration, or causing loss of power of erection due to spinal injury). (Option C)
  2. Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
  3. Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  4. Privation of any member (part, organ, limb) or joints
  5. Destruction or permanent impairing of powers of any member or joint.
  6. Permanent disfiguration of head or face.
  7. Fracture or dislocation of a bone or a tooth. (Option B and D ruled out)
  8. Any hurt which endangers life, or which causes the sufferer to be, during the space of 15 days, in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his daily routine. (Option A)

questions.text: The authority who investigates the death of a 14-year-old girl who was abducted by a man and subsequently died while in police custody will be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Judicial magistrate

Explanation:As per Section 176 CrPC (Code of Criminal Procedure, India), when a person dies in police custody or under suspicious circumstances, the investigation must be conducted by a Judicial Magistrate.

Key Reasons:

  • Judicial Magistrate ensures an impartial and independent inquiry.

Mandatory for cases involving:

  • Death in police custody.
  • Death of minors under suspicious circumstances.
  • Death due to abduction or unnatural causes.

Coroner (Option A): Outdated in India, previously investigated unnatural deaths.

Police (Option B): Cannot investigate deaths occurring in their custody independently due to conflict of interest.

Medical Examiner (Option C): Conducts autopsies but does not have legal authority for formal investigation.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother with a complaint of abdominal pain. The patient's urine pregnancy test (UPT) is positive. What should be the first step by you as a medical officer?

choices.text: Take consent from the patient's mother

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inform the police

Explanation:

  • In cases involving minors with a positive pregnancy test, suspicion of sexual assault or abuse must be considered. The first step is to notify the police, as per the Protection of Children from Sexual Offenses (POCSO) Act, which mandates mandatory reporting of such cases to protect the child and initiate an investigation.

Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act

  • Enacted in 2012, it is law in India designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse, sexual harassment, and pornography.

Key Features of the POCSO Act:

  • Gender-neutral law
  • It covers penetrative and non-penetrative assault, sexual harassment, and use of children for pornography
  • Burden of proof is on the accused, unlike many other criminal laws where the burden is on the prosecution
  • Mandatory reporting by adults and failure to do so can be punishable
  • Special courts for the trial of offenses to ensure a child-friendly environment
  • Identity of the victim is to be protected, and the proceedings are to be conducted in camera to prevent exposure

Recent Changes and Developments in the POCSO Act:

  • 2019 Amendment
    • Stricter Punishments: Death penalty for aggravated sexual assault against children
    • The minimum punishment for penetrative sexual assault increased to 10 years, and for aggravated penetrative sexual assault increased to 20 years, with the possibility of life imprisonment or death in extreme cases.
  • Fast-track Courts to ensure swift disposal of POCSO cases, given the backlog of pending cases.
  • Clarifications on ‘Touch’ and Sexual Intent:
    • The intent behind physical contact is crucial in determining whether it qualifies as an offense under POCSO.
  • Digital Crimes Against Children:
    • Provisions related to the use of children for pornographic and online exploitation purposes have been emphasized with stricter penalties.

questions.text: A forensic expert received a summons from the district court to record his evidence in a criminal case, but two days prior, he already received a summons for a civil case in the same district court for the same date. What should the doctor do?

choices.text: Attend the court for which the summons came first.
Attend the court for the criminal case.

questions.solution:
• Criminal cases take precedence over civil cases due to their public importance and urgency.
  • The forensic expert must attend the criminal case and inform the civil court about the conflict, requesting a rescheduled date.
  • Ignoring a court summons can lead to legal consequences, so prioritizing the criminal case is mandatory.

 

Summons/Subpoena:

  • A subpoena is a legal order mandating a witness to appear before a court on a specific date, time, and location to provide testimony or evidence, under penalty.
  • A subpoena is issued by the court in writing, signed by the presiding officer, and carries the court's official seal (Sec. 63 BNSS).
  • Delivered to the witness by a police officer, court official, or public servant.
  • The witness must sign and return a duplicate copy of the subpoena to acknowledge receipt (Sec. 64 BNSS).

 

Types of Subpoenas

  1. Subpoena duces tecum:
    • The witness is required to bring specific documents or items to the court (e.g., medico-legal reports or postmortem findings).
    • For expert witness.
  2. Subpoena ad testificandum:
    • The witness is required to appear in court to provide oral testimony.
    • For common witnesses.

 

Punishment for Failing to Comply with a Subpoena/Summons:

1. Civil Cases:

  • The witness may be ordered to pay damages for failing to attend court. This involves compensation for the inconvenience caused to the parties involved in the case.

2. Criminal Cases:

If a witness fails to appear in court without a justified reason, the following actions can be taken:

  • Under 63 – 71 BNSS, the court may issue a notice to the witness to explain their absence.
  • The court may issue notice under Section 389, BNSS and after hearing the witness, if it finds that the witness neglected to attend the court without a justified reason, may punish him under Section 208 and 209, BNS, and sentence him/her to:
    • A fine (Rs.1000/-), OR
    • Imprisonment (6 months), OR
    • Both fine and imprisonment.
  • Also, the Court may issue bailable or non-bailable warrants to secure the presence of the witness (S.206 to 209, BNS and S.90, BNSS).

 

Prioritization of Summons:

  • Criminal vs. Civil Courts: If a witness is summoned by both criminal and civil courts for the same day, they must attend the criminal court, which takes precedence.
  • Higher vs. Lower Courts: When summoned by two courts of the same jurisdiction (e.g., civil or criminal), the witness must attend the higher court first.
  • Multiple Summons: If the witness receives multiple summonses from the same type of court, they should attend the court that issued the first summons and notify the other.

 

Inform both courts and wait (Option A): While informing both courts is a good step, simply waiting without attending either court is not advisable, as it could lead to legal consequences.

 

Attend the court for which the summons came first (Option B): The order in which the summons were received does not determine priority. The nature of the case (criminal vs. civil) takes precedence.

 

Do not attend either court (Option D): Ignoring court summons can result in contempt of court or other legal penalties.

questions.text: A married female died in unnatural condition within 3 years of marriage. Her father filed a report to police and inquiry will be done under which section?
questions.solution:
In cases of a married woman's unnatural death within 7 years of marriage, a Magistrate-led inquiry is mandatory under Section 176 CrPC (or Section 196 BNSS). This ensures a thorough and impartial investigation, especially when foul play, suicide, or dowry-related violence is suspected.

 

In India, there are two types of inquests: police inquest and magistrate inquest.

 

1. Police Inquest (Section 194, BNSS)

  • Most common type of inquest in India.
  • Conducted by a police officer, generally not below the rank of Head Constable.

The police officer, upon receiving information about the unnatural death, visits the site.

↓

Involves two or more witnesses from the local area, called panchas, to assist in the investigation. The report is referred to as a panchnama.

↓

If the cause of death appears to be accidental or non-suspicious, the body is handed over to the family for funeral proceedings.

↓

In case of suspicious circumstances, the police officer forwards the body for a postmortem to a certified medical officer and sends the report to the Magistrate.

 

2. Magistrate Inquest (Section 196, BNSS)

  • Conducted by an Executive Magistrate, or Judicial Magistrate.
  • It's mandatory in specific circumstances, including:
    • Death, the disappearance of a person, or alleged rape in police custody or any custody authorized by the court
    • Deaths due to police firing
    • Deaths in jail
    • Deaths of women within 7 years of marriage if,
      • Commits suicide
      • In any circumstances raising a reasonable suspicion that some other person committed an offence
      • Any relative of the woman has made a request on this behalf
      • There is any doubt regarding the cause of death
    • Deaths where there's suspicion of rape before death
    • Deaths with suspicion of foul play or where a relative of the deceased has made a request
  • Also conducted if the case is referred by police due to suspicion arising during their investigation
  • An inquiry by a Judicial Magistrate or Metropolitan Magistrate is required in instances of custodial death, disappearance, or custodial rape where foul play is suspected or there are allegations of an offense. In all other situations, the inquiry can be conducted by an Executive Magistrate.
  • The magistrate is responsible for forwarding the body for postmortem examination to a Civil Surgeon or another authorized doctor within 24 hours of the death.

 

Differences Between Police and Magistrate Inquests:

Feature

Police Inquest

Magistrate Inquest

Conducted by

Police officer

Magistrate (DM, SDM, Judicial, or Executive Magistrate)

Involvement of witnesses

Requires signatures of panchas

Does not require witness signatures

Witness statements

Admissible in court

Not admissible in court

Can order arrest

No, but can arrest in cognizable offenses

Can issue arrest warrants

Exhumation

Cannot order exhumation

Can order exhumation of a body

Autopsy orders

Sends bodies for autopsy indiscriminately

Orders autopsy only when necessary

Forensic analysis

Cannot order chemical analysis of viscera

Can order chemical analysis

questions.text: Who order the autopsy in case of RTA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Police:

In cases of Road Traffic Accidents (RTA), the police are responsible for ordering an autopsy to determine the cause of death. This is part of their duty to investigate the circumstances surrounding the death and to ensure proper legal procedures are followed. The police will request an autopsy if there is a need to understand the cause of death more clearly or if it is required for legal reasons.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Forensic expert:

A forensic expert conducts the autopsy but does not order it. The role of the forensic expert is to perform the examination and provide a report based on their findings.

Option C - Lawyer:

A lawyer may request an autopsy as part of legal proceedings, but they do not have the authority to order an autopsy in cases of RTA. Their role is generally more related to the legal representation of the parties involved.

Option D - Forensic doctor:

Similar to the forensic expert, the forensic doctor performs the autopsy but does not order it. The forensic doctor provides medical expertise in the examination and interpretation of findings.

questions.text: Which article in the constitution does not pertain to children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Article 42:

  • 42," is the correct answer as it is not directly related to children.

  • Article 42 of the Indian Constitution focuses on the provision of just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Article 21A: Article 21A of the Indian Constitution relates to the Right to Education. It states that the State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children in the age group of 6 to 14 years.

Option B - Article 24: Article 24 of the Indian Constitution deals with the prohibition of child labor.

Option C - Article 45: Article 45 of the Indian Constitution pertains to the provision of early childhood care and education for children below the age of six years.

questions.text: The first-hand knowledge rule is applicable to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Common witness:

  • The first-hand knowledge rule, also known as the firsthand or personal knowledge rule, is applicable to a common witness. A common witness is an individual who has observed or experienced an event directly and can provide testimony based on their own personal knowledge of the event.

  • The first-hand knowledge rule requires that a witness's testimony be based on facts or information that they themselves have perceived through their own senses

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hand writing expert: They rely on their specialized knowledge and training rather than personal observation or direct experience of the events related to the handwriting.

Option C - Doctor: A doctor may provide expert testimony based on their professional knowledge and experience rather than personal observation or direct experience of a specific event.

Option D - Hostile witness: A hostile witness is a witness who is unwilling or uncooperative in providing testimony.the first-hand knowledge rule is not specifically applicable to hostile witnesses.

questions.text: What is the appropriate course of action following the observation of cigarette burn marks on the forearm of a 14-year-old girl who presents to a doctor with a fractured forearm, claiming to have fallen and hit her hand?

choices.text: To do a complete physical examination
To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse
To call local social worker for help

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - To do a complete physical examination:

  •  When a 14-year-old girl presents with a fractured forearm and reports that she fell and hit her hand, it is essential for the doctor to conduct a thorough physical examination to assess the extent of the injury and evaluate any associated findings.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - To inform higher authorities: While it is important to address suspicions of abuse Before involving higher authorities, it is crucial to gather more information through a comprehensive examination.

Option C - To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse: Discussing the case with colleagues can provide additional insights, but it is necessary to gather more information through a comprehensive examination before making any definitive conclusions.

Option D - To call a local social worker for help: To call a local social worker for help: In cases where abuse is suspected,it is crucial to gather more information through a thorough physical examination and, if needed, reporting to higher authorities before contacting a social worker

questions.text: If a healthcare professional is found guilty of professional misconduct, they must provide the patient's records promptly upon request, within:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 72 hours:

  • In cases of professional misconduct, when a patient requests their medical records, the healthcare provider is obligated to provide the records within a specific timeframe. The correct timeframe for providing patient records on demand in the case of professional misconduct is typically within 72 hours.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation for the correct answer.

questions.text: When an individual commences employment with a second employer, the new employer assumes responsibility for the individual's actions, under which doctrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Borrowed servant doctrine:

  • When a person starts working for a second employer, the new employer may assume responsibility for their actions under the Borrowed Servant Doctrine.
  • This doctrine applies when an employee is temporarily loaned or "borrowed" by another employer. In such cases, the borrowing employer assumes control over the borrowed employee and becomes responsible for their actions within the scope of their employment during the loaned period.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vicarious liability: Vicarious liability refers to a situation where one person or entity is held responsible for the actions of another person or entity.

Option B - Doctrine of negligent choice: The Doctrine of negligent choice refers to a legal principle that holds a party liable for choosing a negligent individual or entity to perform a task.

Option C - Contributory negligence: Contributory negligence assigns partial blame to a plaintiff for their own injuries or damages due to their failure to exercise reasonable care.

questions.text: Death registration in India done within?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 21 days:

  • In India, death registration is required to be done within 21 days (Option A) of the occurrence of the death. The Registrar of Births and Deaths, usually located at the local municipality or panchayat, is responsible for recording deaths and issuing death certificates.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D: These options do not correspond to the prescribed time frame for death registration in India, which is 21 days.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was rescued from a village in Bihar where she had been sold off by her father for Rs. 25000 to a 45-year-old man. On examination, she was found to be 12 weeks pregnant. She was granted permission to abort the pregnancy, taking into consideration the age of the girl and the circumstances of her pregnancy. A doctor who will be eligible to perform the abortion for this girl should have performed at least how many MTP prior to this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 25: 

  • According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act in India, a doctor must have performed at least 25 MTPs (Option C) to be eligible to perform the abortion for this girl. This criterion ensures that the doctor has sufficient experience and expertise in performing safe and legal abortions.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D - 10, 15 & 35: These options do not meet the requirement of having performed at least 25 MTPs as per the law.

questions.text: A doctor was summoned as a public witness to appear and record his evidence in court. What is correct about this witness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Expert witness

  • This is the correct answer. An expert witness is someone who possesses specialized knowledge, skills, or expertise in a particular field that is relevant to the case. In the given scenario, a doctor is summoned as a witness. If the doctor's testimony is related to their medical expertise and is meant to provide insight and explanation to the court on medical matters, then they would be considered an expert witness

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oral evidence: Oral evidence refers to the testimony or statements provided by witnesses verbally in court. This option does not accurately describe the scenario in which a doctor is summoned as a witness. The scenario mentioned doesn't specifically emphasize the mode of evidence (oral or written) but focuses on the role of the witness.

Option B - Common witness: There is no standard term called "common witness." Witnesses can be categorized based on various factors, but this terminology isn't commonly used. The scenario doesn't provide enough information to suggest that the doctor in question is a "common witness."

Option D - Hostile witness: A hostile witness is a term used to describe a witness who is uncooperative or openly antagonistic towards the party that called them to testify. This option is not applicable to the scenario provided, where a doctor is summoned as a public witness to record evidence in court.

questions.text: Which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) is associated with the penalization of perjury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Section 193 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC):

  • Section 193 of the IPC deals with the offense of giving false evidence in a judicial proceeding It specifies that whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence intending it to be used in a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment and/or a fine.

  • This section specifically addresses the punishment of perjury, which involves knowingly making false statements while under oath during a court proceeding.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Section 191: Section 191 of the IPC deals with the offense of giving false evidence

Option B - Section 192: Section 192 of the IPC relates to the offense of fabricating false evidence.

Option D - Section 197: Under Section 197, if a person in an official capacity knowingly issues or signs a false certificate, they can be punished with imprisonment and or a fine.

questions.text: What is the responsibility of the doctor in recording the dying declaration of a victim affected by a fire?

choices.text: To record the statement even in the presence of magistrate
Put the person under oath before declaration

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - To assess compos mentis:

  • When a dying declaration is being recorded, the role of the doctor is to assess the mental capacity of the person making the statement, also known as "compos mentis."
  • The doctor evaluates whether the person is of sound mind and capable of providing a coherent and reliable statement.
  • This assessment helps determine the admissibility and credibility of the dying declaration as evidence in legal proceedings.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - To record the statement even in the presence of a magistrate: It is not the role of the doctor to record the statement in the presence of a magistrate

Option C - Cross-examine the person: Cross-examination is a legal procedure conducted by legal professionals, such as lawyers or prosecutors. It is not the role of the doctor to cross-examine the person giving the dying declaration.

Option D - Put the person under oath before declaration: The doctor's role in recording a dying declaration does not involve putting the person under oath.

questions.text: An 11 year old girl was found to be quiet and shy in her classroom with intermittent crying, for the past few days. It was discovered that her uncle was touching her genitals inappropriately. The duty of the principal is to report this to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Police:

  • Reporting the incident to the police is crucial because they have the authority and responsibility to investigate cases of child abuse, including inappropriate touching or sexual abuse.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Magistrate: The police are the appropriate authority to handle the initial investigation and take immediate action to protect the child.

Option C - Child welfare committee: Child welfare committees play a crucial role in child protection, but the immediate action in cases of abuse is to report to the police.

Option D - Parents: While it is important to inform the parents or guardians of the child about the incident, the primary responsibility of the principal in such cases is to report to the police.

questions.text: Medical termination of pregnancy can be done upto 24 weeks in case of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D -Rape victim:

  • Medical termination of pregnancy can be done upto 24 weeks in case of rape victims

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fetus malformation: Medical termination of pregnancy can be done beyond 24 weeks if the fetus is found to have severe malformations or abnormalities that are incompatible with life or would result in significant physical or mental challenges for the child.

Option B - Minors: Minors generally require parental or guardian consent for medical procedures, including abortion. The laws regarding abortion for minors can vary by country and jurisdiction, but typically there are provisions for involving parents or guardians in the decision-making process.

Option C - Contraception failure: Medical termination of pregnancy is not typically allowed solely due to contraception failure. However, if the failure of contraception leads to unwanted pregnancy and the woman's health or life is at risk, abortion might be considered based on medical assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements does not apply during cross-examination in a court of law?

choices.text: Witness is examined by the defense lawyer
Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent
There is no time limit to cross examination

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Leading questions are not allowed:

  • Leading questions are not allowed is an incorrect statement regarding cross-examination in a court of law. In fact, leading questions are often used during cross-examination to elicit specific information or to challenge the witness's testimony, under section 143 IEA. Therefore, the statement "Leading questions are not allowed" does not apply during cross-examination in a court of law.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Witness is examined by the defense lawyer: That statement applies during cross-examination in a court of law. The defense lawyer has the right to cross-examine the witness in order to test their credibility and the reliability of their testimony.

Option C - Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent: The objective of cross-examination is to challenge the credibility, accuracy, and completeness of the witness's testimony, and to weaken the case presented by the opposing party. The cross-examining lawyer aims to extract information that may undermine the witness's testimony or support their own case.

Option D - There is no time limit to cross examination: The specific time limits may vary depending on the jurisdiction and the specific rules of the court, but they are generally in place to ensure that the trial proceeds in an efficient and timely manner.

questions.text: As an internal medicine consultant at a private clinic, you are handling the case of a patient who has chronic renal disease and needs hemodialysis. You provide dietary and fluid management recommendations and closely monitor the patient. Unfortunately, the patient decides to take ayurvedic supplements and occasionally disregards your instructions without informing you. Consequently, the patient's condition deteriorates, leading to respiratory distress. Subsequently, the patient's attendant files a legal complaint, accusing the doctor of negligence. Which of the following can serve as a defense for the doctor in court?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Contributory negligence

 

Explanation:

 

Contributory negligence is a valid legal defence in medical negligence cases. It applies when the patient (or their caregiver) fails to follow medical advice or engages in actions that contribute to their own harm, which reduces or nullifies the liability of the doctor.

In this case:

  • The doctor gave appropriate care and advice.

  • The patient disregarded medical instructions and used alternative (ayurvedic) therapies.

  • These actions directly contributed to the deterioration of the condition.

  • Indian courts recognize contributory negligence as a valid defense in medical negligence cases. If it is shown that the patient’s non-compliance or independent actions played a role in the adverse outcome, the doctor’s liability can be reduced or even negated

Thus, contributory negligence can protect the doctor from full liability.

 

Vicarious liability (Option A):

  • Refers to liability of an employer (e.g., hospital) for the actions of its employee.

  • Does not apply to a private consultant being sued personally.

Res Ipsa loquitur (Option B):

  • Means "the thing speaks for itself".

  • Used when negligence is obvious, e.g., leaving a surgical instrument inside the body.

  • In this case, the deterioration was not clearly due to the doctor's action.

Therapeutic misadventure (Option C):

  • Refers to an adverse event despite proper therapy, typically unavoidable or rare.

  • Not applicable here as the decline was due to non-compliance, not an unexpected drug reaction or intervention.

questions.text: According to the amendment in the medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) Bill of 2020, until what gestational age is it permissible to induce MTP in mentally ill rape victims?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 24 weeks:

  • As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2020, the limit for termination of pregnancy in a mentally ill woman or a woman who is a survivor of rape has been increased from 20 weeks to 24 weeks of gestation. 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - 20 weeks: The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2020, t, has increased the gestational limit for termination of pregnancy in certain cases from 20 weeks to 24 weeks.

Option B - 22 weeks: As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2020, the gestational age limit for termination of pregnancy in cases of rape, incest, and vulnerable women, including mentally ill women, has been increased from 20 weeks to 24 weeks.

Option D - 28 weeks: Beyond 24 weeks, termination of pregnancy is only allowed in cases of substantial fetal abnormalities or if the continuation of the pregnancy poses a risk to the life of the mother.
